content: I am confused. Yes, you can create filters that put different messages into special folders, but I don't grasp the desire for a ping when eventually opening the message. The concept of a noise when mail arrives was to let the user know that new mail arrived. But in your situation, you know the message is there and make a conscious decision to open it - so why would you want the ping? Thank you.
creator: davidsk

content: Not sure what you want. Thunderbird lets you move to trash, delete, and compact folders after removal, so what is it that you're seeking? Thanks.
creator: davidsk

content: Your earlier perception is correct: Thunderbird is an email client to manage email accounts, but does not itself provide email accounts. If you're seeking free email accounts, there is always Gmail and Outlook, and a web search would likely bring up several more.
creator: davidsk

content: Try File>get new messages for>youraccountname
creator: davidsk

content: Is this a search or a filter? Maybe if you show the pane of the actual search or filter, someone may have suggestions. Thank you.
creator: davidsk

content: I think you're referring to Gmail. Gmail creates multiple folders for a complete inventory and the folders are not really folders, they are labels. That is each email message exists once, but Gmail has several indices that point to it. That is why I always attempt to discourage users from subscribing to 'folders' such as Allmail, as that includes all mail, including trash. So, to solve your issue, I suggest you unsubscribe from those all encompassing gmail folders.
creator: davidsk

content: A comment: 1. Be sure all folders are set for allowing offline access. 2. to get all the messages be sure to do File>offline>download . Once you have that, you can exit TB, copy the folders from the IMAP account to your Local Folders folder and then you can access the messages in Thunderbird after closing the account.

content:
Stai installando direttamente dentro Thunderbird o dal browser?

Un metodo che puoi tentare:

  • Apri la pagina del dizionario nel browser
  • Click con il tasto destro sul bottone di download e scegli -> salva destinazione come
  • Salva il file
  • Avvia Thunderbird ed apri la schede delle estensioni (tasto menu > componenti aggiuntivi)
  • Trascina il file su questa scheda

creator: tom.gossler

content:
- click settings>general and scroll down to config editor - search for toolkit.legacyUserProfileCustomizations.stylesheets and change to true - then you need a folder named 'chrome' in profile, and a userChrome.css file in the folder (with content shown below). - exit and restart TB and it should work, although I've sometimes found I have to restart TB twice to see changes in userChrome.css - Below is content for userChrome.css 

/*  #######    */ @namespace html url("http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml");  #toolbar-menubar {   order: 1;              }  unified-toolbar {   order: 2;              }  #tabs-toolbar {   order: 3;               }
creator: davidsk
